prompt:
Is the person who wrote this in the wrong in the following situation?

"""
WIBTA if I make my gf start paying some of the bills over a single incident?
Gf and I live together.   She only works part time.    I pay all the rent and bill.  I never minded it until last night. 

We went to grab some take out and I realized I left my wallet in my work pants.  I told her she’d have to get it.   Her attitude about the whole thing was so ugly.   At first she couldn’t believe it and asked me if I was serious in this almost disgusted tone.  She acted so put out by it. 

It was some fucking take out.  Under $40.  I pay EVERYTHING.  I understand she only makes a little, but that little is probably a lot with no expenses.   I know it was only one incident, but I haven’t been able to get it out of my head since.   It’s really rubbing my the wrong way.  She wouldn’t be able to pay a lot of the bills, but I feel like it’s time for her to start carrying her weight.  Just out of principal.  
"""

Is the author in the wrong? Answer A for Yes (the author is in the wrong) and B for No (the author is not in the wrong). Answer nothing else.

thinking.text:
Okay, let's try to figure out if the author is in the wrong here. So, the situation is that the author and their girlfriend live together. He pays all the rent and bills because she only works part-time. The problem started when he forgot his wallet and asked her to pay for takeout, which was under $40. She got upset about it, and now he's considering making her start contributing to the bills, even though he acknowledges she can't pay a lot.

First, I need to think about the dynamics here. The author has been paying everything so far, which he didn't mind until this incident. The girlfriend's reaction was negative—disbelief, disgust, being put out. The author is frustrated because even a small amount like $40 was a problem for her, and he wants her to take on more responsibility. 

Now, the question is whether he's in the wrong by making her pay some bills after this one incident. Let's break it down. 

From the author's perspective: He's been covering all expenses, which is a big commitment. He feels that this one incident showed her not being on board with contributing, even a little. He might feel that fairness requires some contribution, especially since she has some income, even if it's part-time. Maybe he's trying to set boundaries for the future to prevent resentment.

From the girlfriend's perspective: She works part-time, so her income is limited. Maybe she has her own expenses and wasn't expecting to contribute to the bills. The sudden request for her to pay the takeout might have been a shock, especially if she's not used to contributing. Her reaction might stem from feeling that the request was unfair given her financial situation or perhaps from feeling that the author has never expected her to contribute before, so this was unexpected and maybe a test or an ultimatum.

Now, considering whether the author is in the wrong. If the author has never discussed financial responsibilities before, and this is the first time he's asked her to contribute, and then he's using this one incident to make a big change, that could be seen as unfair. Relationships require communication, and maybe he should have talked about splitting costs earlier rather than springing it on her after a single event. 

Also, the amount in question is relatively small ($40), so her being put out might be because she felt it was out of nowhere. The author might be overreacting to a minor incident, using it as a justification to change the financial arrangement, which could be seen as holding a grudge or being unfair. 

On the other hand, if the author feels that the relationship is unfair because he's covering everything and wants her to contribute even a little, that's a reasonable expectation. However, the way he's approaching it—after one incident and without prior discussion—might be problematic. It's possible that the author is in the wrong because he's making a significant change in their financial agreement based on a minor, single event without having an open conversation about their expectations. 

So, considering all that, I think the answer is A (Yes, the author is in the wrong) because he's reacting to a single incident without prior communication, which could be seen as unfair. The right approach would be to discuss financial responsibilities together rather than unilaterally deciding to change things after a minor conflict.
